This bracket holds a Mintyboost from Adafruit in place of the bulb assembly in a 3-D cell Maglite Flashlight. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/9ioujFlW9oI

The Mintyboost from Adafruit is an excellent battery powered USB charger circuit.  It was designed to use 2 AA cells and be housed in a mini altoid tin container.   I was looking for significantly higher capacity and a rugged housing, and stumbled over my 3D cell aluminum Maglite.  Removing the bulb and reflector, I created a space to hold the mintyboost board.  By disassembling (breaking) a bulb, power can be drawn from the bulb socket.
I sliced it in Makerware, medium quality (.27 layers, 2 shells, 0% infill).  It sticks to the plate like glue -- take your time and a nice spudger to get it off...
The original upload was corrupted, so deleted and re-added the file on 3/11.

Grabber arm for robot
A collection of separate eyes, noses and mouths, each set on its own layer, for a customized jack-o-lantern/ghost face to be printed with the Eggbot.

To use the file, open layers and click the eye icon to make the desired face layers unhidden. Select them all together, then copy. "Paste in place" (under Edit) onto the "1 face" layer. Use the Layers tab in the Eggbot extension to print layer 1.   
Also included is an oval for an orange background (layer 2) and a test layer (layer 3) with lines to make sure the designs will fit. The smaller space accommodates all the face pieces, the larger is for the orange circle.   
These were made to print on ping pong balls. You may need to adjust for eggs and other less regularly shaped items.   
I have included a "faces menu" PDF so that you can clearly review your choices. This was really helpful in a classroom situation.

Low poly dog bone for dogs to play with.
This is a custom 8-way restrictor plate for an arcade joystick.

The joysticks I got for my arcade cabinet (http://www.arcadewinkel.nl/joysticks/balltop-arcadefighter-stick-rood) were fine, but I wasn't entirely happy with the restrictor plates that came with it. They worked fine in 4-way mode, but the 8-way mode was simply a square and that doesn't work nicely in most circumstances. From what I can tell, the screws are placed differently on all joystick brands, so YMMV if you have a different one. I included the scad file if you want to play around with it (but it's not nicely parameterized). There's not really much to instruct here:
  • Stop playing on arcade cabinet
  • Print restrictor plate(s)
  • Remove existing restrictor plate(s)
  • Place printed restrictor plate(s)

comments.text: This worked a treat the original plate had me switching between 4 - 8 way to be able to play 4 way games without issue this plate just works fine for all so no more fiddly switching.

comments.text: Thank you so much for this. Is there any chance you could make the same restrictor, but circular instead of octagonal? I have an ultrastik 360, and was curious about trying out a circular restrictor in it as it's an analog joystick.

description.text:
Fits 1 (one)  16x2 LCD in a 5x2x12 Brick.  This mount is intended to basically hold up a 16x2 LCD for prototyping some ideas.
The brick itself is equal to 5 (2x12) Lego bricks. So it can be "bricked" into a nice support structure to hold it in place.
A huge help when you are trying to make something and don't want your LCD out and loose.

• Print it Face Down.

  • I modify the "Medium" settings:
    Quality: Layer Height = 0.12
    Temperature: 240
    • All other defaults are the same.

  • Print it Face Down.

  • In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings:
    Quality: Layer Height = 0.16
    • All other defaults are the same. If you don't have a 3D printer we can make you one pretty cheap.. badbrick.com/catalog

When pouring epoxy on items where the epoxy will run off the edge, the item needs to be raised so the item does not bond to the back of the item. This is often called a bed of nails.
As an example, if you make a clock from old tree root slices. You would drive nails through a board to set the wood on, then you would pour epoxy over it until it completely coats it and the excess would drip off the edges on the board with nails.
This is a smaller version for doing jewelry or other small items. It has prongs sticking up and has a troth around the edge to catch run off.
Nothing special. But it's a good idea to coat with a mold release or spray wax before using so the dried epoxy can be removed.

title: Tea Caddy used at the Edenton Tea Party in 1774

description.text: This tea caddy comes from the North Carolina Museum of History's collection. According to the museum's records, it was used at the Edenton Tea Party in Edenton, NC in 1774. The Edenton Tea Party is widely recognized as one of the first acts of political protest organized by women in pre-Revolutionary America. For more information about this and other anti-tea actions of colonial women, see this blog post that interprets the history behind the Tea Caddy. A colored, more realistic 3D model of the caddy can be found here. Citation Information:

Accession #: H.1914.187.1
Date: 1774
Place: Edenton, Chowan, North Carolina, USA
Dimensions: [Lt] [Wdt]3 11/16" [Ht]5 5/16" [Dt]1 3/4"
Materials: Porcelain

To create the 3D image of the Tea Caddy, our team used 123D Catch, an application produced by Autodesk. 123D Catch converts ordinary photos in 3D models. 123D Catch is a free application and objects are stored and made accessible on the cloud. Our team photographed the Tea Caddy thirty-five times at different angles using an iPhone 6. The 123D Catch app then melded the photos together and saved it on the cloud. After downloading the image from the 123D Catch web app, we deleted extraneous data using MeshLab, a free software program. We then proceeded to use netfabb Basic to clean up the item and give it a flat bottom.

author: hrmoll13

description.text:
The frost really came this morning, and my "new" Golf wasnt equipped with an Ice Scraper, so I had to make one :)
This is my Ice Scraper made to look like the Swedish flag.
It can easily be printed as either the Finnish or Danish flag as well.
And some other countries.
I might make a Norwegian flag if some one wants it. This project was made possible by www.protech.se

Remember that if you print this in solid model interior the model design is prone to warping.
Theres really no way to get around this on a MakerBot to my knowlage. You could try to print with a higher temp if you have problems with warping.
The 2X would want a higher temp on the build table.
If your using Insight, a good way to print it is to use more contours, found under custom groups, and sparse high densety interior.
In insight and catalyst the pause can be inserted during the slizing and the printer will pause automaticly, remember it will pause before it starts with the layer containing the pause.
In Makerbot Desktop you currently need to manually pause during the print. This is different on each machine so figure it out first.
The part must be printed as is, laying on it's back to get "multi colour", since the design must be paused in Z.

made by 3d printing comitee

I was looking for a Duplo helicopter for my nephew for Christmas but couldn't find one with just a helicopter so I made one. He's 3 so I wanted to keep it simple and only put 2x2 Duplo sized studs in the cockpit for a Duplo figure and made the rest kind of fisher-pricey. Works well with all the Duplo bricks I have tried with it so far. I was having some printing issues with larger objects so I also tried it at 1/2 scale which makes the studs regular lego size. I guess the printer isn't up to the tighter tolerances needed for lego because at this scale the lego parts are a bit hard to get on though they do work.
I think of my self as an artist and not an engineer so the tolerances are less than great and it may have some pretty big design and structural issues. My 1:1 Duplo print mostly clicked together and holds without glue but I had to clean and sand some of the parts a little bit more than I would have liked to make it work. Had to really sand the holes for the rotors so they would spin freely. I printed these on my UP! with the normal and .25 mm settings. Maybe with fine and .20mm settings it would work a bit better?

Print and clean up parts. Sand top, bottom and inside of rotor holes and the post part of the rotor pegs till they slide on and spin freely.
Snap together.
Mine all clicked together and held. Might be a good idea to add a little glue before snapping together to make it a bit stronger.
Oh, there are two rotors. I liked the original slightly larger rotor I made but it didn't fit on my UP! so I made a slightly smaller version. Either will work and the smaller UP! version is in my photos on the Duplo 1:1 print while the 1/2 scale print has the full size rotor since it fit on the printer at that size.

title: Laser cut Nixie Tube clock powered by Arduino

description.text: I bought all the goodies to make a nice Nixie clock from Taylor Electronics, but I didn't have a nice case for it. It took me about 6 hours to design, cut,  and re-cut parts until I had something I was happy with. I disabled the I2C master on the first TES 1361 SmartNixie board and replaced it with an Arduino Nano board connected in the unused RTC connector on the bottom of the backplane board. I poll the GPS RTC board via I2C to get the time and then send command over the I2C bus to the SmartNixie boards to display the digits.

Laser cut parts from 1/8 acrylic (The stuff I bought from Home Depot ended up being 2.2mm thick and not 3.175mm(1/8") so this drawing was designed for 2.2mm, but that isn't hard to change.) Order these parts from http://www.tayloredge.com/storefront/index.html 1 x 1392 - 6 Digit IN18 Clock Backplane 6 x 1361 - SmartNixie IN18 1 x 1375 - SmartNixie GPS RTC 1 x 1364 - SmartNixie HVPS-H 1 x Active GPS Antenna 1 x Power Plug I ordered my IN-18 tubes from super-gene on ebay: http://myworld.ebay.com/super-gene/ 6 x IN-18 tubes 12V power supply and Arduino Nano can be ordered from Amazon here: http://www.amazon.com/Wall-Adapter-Power-Supply-12VDC/dp/B006GEPUYA http://www.amazon.com/Arduino-ARD-NANO30-Nano-v3-0/dp/B003YVL34O Arduino Sketch: http://blog.jasongarland.com/2013/02/laser-cut-nixie-tube-clock-powered-by.html#more

comments.text:

comments.text: Hi, I figured it out. DS1 is the clock master because S0 is open, and that creates an address with LSB set to 1.  This in I2C addressing designates a master. So simply flipping A1 on DS1 to the ON position will create an address that has LSB set to 0 or 1110.  The Arduino is now able to communicate.

OpenScad designed rack to mount filament on the wall, or on the side of the printer.  Holds two spools on each.
This thing has moved to Youmagine https://www.youmagine.com/users/jensa so I don't also get sued by Stratasys... Small sign I made for displaying info and price for products.

We use this in our hackerspace in the mini-shop holding Arduino's, Raspberry PI's, breadboards, Sparkfun-kits and other fun. It's a two-piece assembly that snaps together with a small lock. Just print out labels that are 50 x 23mm and put them into the sign. There's also room for putting a plastic sheet of similar size in front of the paper piece to make it last longer and look more professional.
The structure is hollow to save filament and this also allows you to put something inside for weight. The two parts are press-fit and weigh less than 5 grams. Walls are 1 mm thick so they're easy to print with both 0.5mm and smaller nozzles.
I've also added the Rhino-file in case someone want's to modify it. This has both the booled and unbooled elements for easy modding.

title: Replacement Hinge Peg for Black & Decker WMB500 Belgian Waffle Maker

description.text:
***UPDATE: Version two has thicker walls. I'd been printing a lot of these, and the sides were occasionally breaking off during install. Turns out they don't need to be so thin.
The hinge pegs on my friend's waffle iron disintegrated over time. Eventually, it was unusable. She knew I had just gotten a 3d printer and asked if I could use what was left of one hinge to replace them.  
The geometry looked simple enough, so I spent ~30 min banging out a crude SCAD file. The printed piece looked OK, but I figured "Nah, there's no way it could be this easy."  
Popped right in. Waffle production resumed immediately.  
I actually vapor polished the pieces to harden them a bit, but in my haste I didn't take a photo of the shiny pegs before we installed them. Trust me, they were beautiful.

• Wrote the attached SCAD
  • Rendered an STL
  • Printed the STL with 100% infill using black ABS at 0.3mm layer height
  • Vapor polished the two pieces
  • Shoved them into the hinge holes on the waffle iron

title: Cam Hold Down - GoldenRatio aka Fibonacci Spiral for Shapeoko and Other CNC's

description.text:
Looking for hold down options for your projects? This version uses a 1/4" hole that can be used with many CNC, Laser Cutter and other projects that require a flexible, fast hold down system for anchoring your material.
.
We have been using the CNC's at 757 Makerspace the last few months and using a wide range of materials for projects. One thing we found is that when using a spoiler board (aka sacrificial layer) is that screwing down work puckers up the material and also sometimes interferes with your project material. Recently we have been drilling our spoiler boards to accept 1/4" holes every two inches in the x and y position, this allows us to anchor our material using a wide range of options. The latest design we have been using is the use of a rotating cam to get tighter to materials that vary slightly and settled on the Golden Ratio or Fibonacci Spiral as the basis for the design.
.
If you find this useful, please take a moment to write a comment and click Like. Enjoy and Make On!

There are two designs included; one with a rotating path and the other with two holes.
.
Field Note:
The rotating path is ok, while the two hole design seems to work better (single point of rotation).
.
The original design file is included as a closed polyline in .dwg and .dxf and an extruded version (1/2" in height) as a .stl for anyone interested in printing vs. cutting/milling. Use a suitable bolt or t-nut system, rotate for more pressure and secure your design for cutting.

title: Bearing / Shaft Mount (No Pins) - Da Vinci 1.0 / 2.0 - 3D Printer

description.text:
Design is based on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:382437 I modified the design to remove the pins, which are not really needed, and it makes them much easier to print. ~ Uses a M3 Nut to prevent the plastic from stripping.
~ Much stronger than the stock shaft mount.
~ Easier to print without the pins.

Print with a high infill (40% on Slic3r or 25% on Cura).
I printed mine at 0.2mm Layer Height.

title: Color Gel Holder for LumoPro LP160 Quad Sync Flash

description.text:
• Put this thing on your LumoPro LP160 flash (http://www.lumopro.com/product.php?id=25).
  • Insert a color gel into the slot.
  • Take photos.
    It's designed for color gels with the dimensions 93mm x 50mm.

You'll need a 3D printer to make this.
I printed mine at the FabLab Aachen
(http://hci.rwth-aachen.de/fablab).
This is my first 3D print. What I learned is that it can take quite a while to dissolve the support material inside the very narrow slot. It took almost a week! So I am probably going to edit the design and make the slot a little bit wider. In the current design there's only one layer of support material inside the slot. A wider slot will also make inserting the gels easier.

comments.text: Brilliant!  I use the Lumiquest Gel Holder on one of my flashes but it's not easy to put the gels in and out.  I also have quite a few 285's that need holders.  I think I'll trying printing one of these (with 285 dimensions) tonight.  I'll let you know how it works!

author: pequerhead

description.text:
This first of its kind deer call has a gun barreled inner sound hole; a guarantee to bring in those long distance bucks. This call is fully functional with the addition of just a few O-rings and a reed. Reeds can be purchased for as low as $0.12. Can someone figure out how to print a reed? The adjustment of the O-ring affects the pitch of the deer call; making the call effective for mature bucks, young bucks, does, and fawns. I’ve searched the internet and believe that this may likely be the first every 3D printed buck call. Try it out and let me know what you think.
While people make deer calls out of wood all the time, wood workers are unable to make this spiraled design. This design is actually a 32 sided polygon, revolved 180 degrees. This spiraled design creates interesting illusions to the eye when printed.
There is an inner “collar” that has no function other than to allow an avenue for users to customize their call.

Blow into call.
Prepare your bow.
Ready yourself, aim, and fire.
Mount buck above fireplace.

description.text:
This is a modified version of Thing 184920, a Galaxy Tab 2 stand. I simply adapted it for the Tab 4.
  • Speaker ports removed. The 4 has no speakers there.
  • Slightly narrowed to fit the slimmed-down later model.
  • Connector space completly reworked - the tab 2 has a propritary dock connector, the tab 4 uses micro-USB. I've carefully (ie, eventually, in seven prints) shaped this to be an exact fit for the USB cable that comes with the tablet.
  • Back reworked a little to use less filiment and print faster.
  • Fixed some really bad geometry, like burried faces and assymetry.
    • It works pretty well. The only problem I found is that it's so lightweight, you can't actually get the tablet out with one hand - the extraction force for the USB connector is greater than the stand weight! I solved this by supergluing it to my desk. It's also a slightly imperfect fit, so you have to wiggle it a little to get the tablet in, but that's really standard for any tablet stand. They never seem to fit exactly, even the ones molded conventionally.

This is a really easy print job. No support material, no fiddling, and a healthy large flat surface on the bottom to keep it on the bed. There's a small bridge on the bottom, where the USB cable goes through, that's the hardest bit. some gentle overhangs too, but nothing that should prove difficult for even the cheapest of printers.

remixed_from.author: Maxxi
remixed_from.title: Heavy duty Vibration damper for Leapfrog Creatr

description.text:
These are vibration damping feet for the 3UP printer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:354802 which was designed by DDeGonge888.
I redisigned these ones https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:94279 to fit the 20 x 20 mm aluminium extrusions, so they should fit on any printer which uses these extrusions.
I did put anti slip pads under the feet, so the movement is actually absorbed by the damping feet.
The damping feet reduced the noise of my 3UP a lot.
I printed them at a layer height of 0.25 mm and 20% infill.

comments.text: I've never unterstanden the principle of these. IMHO, this is not a damping foot (neither dampening^^) but a spring foot. So it will not reduce the vibration. Not that much energy will be dissipated. And you even increase the probability of resonance.
comments.author: chrlg

comments.text:
This was discussed in the original feet aswell.
In my opinion and experience they work as designed. With these feet installed the movement / vibration isn´t transfered to the surface (in my case a table) and that reduces the noise a lot.
This is how industrial machines (i.e. CNC mills) work aswell, with the only exception, that they are bolted to the ground. As I didn´t whant to screw anything to my table I did put anti slip pads under the damping (not dampening (-; ) feet to compensate for that.

title: Strum Trigger for Guitar Hero guitar

description.text:
Had a friend who was complaining about his Guitar Hero guitar being broken. After looking at the plastic bits he was able to salvage I crafted a replacement and printed it on my MakerBot. This is still a work in progress so if you print it you may need to adjust the mesh, he hasn't had time to re-assemble his guitar to confirm everything fits correctly. Two of the 'legs' have square recesses for magnets, while researching the trigger assembly it appears there are 4 types of electrical interfaces, this should fit all 4.
UPDATED 11/14 - I was able to get the actual mechanism and have made adjustments for a better fit. The metal caps on the end of the original trigger fit over the pegs on each piece. Requires the spring return from the original trigger and two small screws to assemble properly.
If you print this please let me know how it works for you, thanks!
Printed at .2mm layers, 10% infill.

Make a custom fit, shaped and embossed, or engraved bracket for you or a special someone.

Do you have a Kossel/Delta with the cartridge rollers moving on the sides of the OpenBeam extrusions? Then you probably are in the same situation as I am: There is no place to tie the wires for the endstops!
.
Well, now there is, on the back of the extrusions.
.
This clip should just plug into the OpenBeam extrusions, and then a wire with a maximum outer diameter of about 2mm (or multiple wires equaling this diameter) should plug right in.
.
Please report if you can't print them for some reason or if your parts end up being too loose on the extrusions!
.
Update: bigger ~10mm clip added
Update: Made the fingers of 10mm clip somewhat tighter to hold smaller, bundled wires, by rounding the opening off. (Version a)

comments.text: The description states that it's a "stylized" prop, if you took the time to read, the Thing Details literally says "Stylized Halloween props for Sword Art Online - Kirito's Attire"; reference images were pulled from the anime, toy line and from various deviantart fan made sketches; there are several examples where the points have rounded edges, there are a few that have them completely made into round circles or even hexes. remixed_from.author: Ndrew
remixed_from.title: The Wobble Ring Stepping Motor MK1

description.text:
This is a snap together version (some glue) of my printable motor. It has been shrunk and uses only 9 pieces, air pistons included. The bellowPiston part is printed with no infill and needs to be airtight. When inflated it extends outward to push the glued on bellowLink part. The bellowLinks then push the wobbleRing, meshing with the drivenGear. Each piston is inflated and deflated sequentially to "step" the motor 4 degrees forward or backwards. This thing is the successor to this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33853 And uses sgcg's fastener library
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15915 Also uses mechadense's epi-hypocycloids from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28237 The bellows used are modeled after this general shape:
http://www.f295.org/main/content.php?120-Paper-Gaffer-s-Tape-Bellows Though I hope this latest version shows much improvement, I realize there is always room for better design. Please, chime in if you see room for improvement. I also have to mention that I have not printed this yet, so I don't know if it will work. Of biggest concern are the bellowPiston parts, because they need to extend at least 2mm to be productive. I also don't know how easy it will be print 45 degree overhangs that are airtight AND slightly flexible.

All parts are oriented for printing without support. Print 1 each of the following:
basePlate.stl
wobbleRing.stl
drivenGear.stl Print 3 of both the bellowPiston.stl part (without infill) and the bellowLink.stl part. Open the bellowPiston parts at the top end by taking off the last layer. Glue together the bellowPistons and bellowLinks. All pieces snap together downward from were they are seen in the exploded view. The wrsmAssembled.stl file shows the completed thing, minus gluing.

title: Flexible helical z-wobble coupler for printrbot jr v2, 5mm to 3/8in

description.text:
Heavily customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:143514
Base mesh created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=143514
Used Blender.app to make boolean screwholes and compression gaps, and fine-tuned mesh size by trial and error.
Mostly eliminates my PBJV2 z-wobble. To Print: You MUST print with support; print with support "lines" instead of "box" support. Carefully remove support after printing. To use: Remove old coupler; attach coupler to 5mm shaft of Z-motor.
Carefully lower the main carriage so the Z-shaft goes into the top
of the coupler. Leave a space inside the coupler between the top of the motor shaft and the bottom of the Z-shaft. Use a 5mm wide rubber band and insert it into the spiral; this prevents vibration and stops the spiral from compressing. Use a shorter M3 screw than I used, so it doesn't stick out and knock against the linear bearings, or catch on the wires of your heated build plate.

Using the following options:
$fn = 100
length_bottom = 10
length_top = 10
screw_diameter = 0
helix_length = 10
hole_dia_bottom = 5
coupling_outer_dia = 20
hole_dia_top = 9.53

A copy of the Cold Steel Delta Dart, as seen below. http://www.coldsteel.com/Product/92DD/DELTA_DART.aspx My design is a shorter version made to fit on the print bed of a Makerbot Replicator. The Delta Dart is ribbed for purpose of maintaining grip. Ribless version also available. Hole on back is for a keychain ring or cord. Pictures don't show it well, but blade is triangular.
Print as strong as possible.  100% infil, 2 shells seems to work best.  Rafting with external support encouraged.

comments.author: Spiderdog06

comments.text: I printed this in on my Prusa i3 kit printer.  Rotated 60deg on the long axis, so an edge is at the bottom (print lying down, not standing up, so you avoid layers on the thin cross-section), so no need for support on the blade, then used a raft and supports to stabilize the handle.   Printed at .2mm layers, 4 shells for protection against breaking at layer boundaries, printed slow (45mm/sec) for strength, with 50% infill

The pieces slide together, it is a little tight but it does not require any screws :)
Fits an Arduino Uno with a Seed Studio Ethernet shield. You can fit a little something on the top which is why I have it a little taller than the Uno and shield.

Printing: Ensure that the main part that has 4 sides prints with the back on the print bed. The other 2 parts should be obvious.
Putting it together: With your Uno and ethernet shield together place the front piece over the ports, then slide it evenly up into the main piece with 4 sides. The back of the Uno and shield will be against the back of the enclousre. After those are together slide the bottom on from the front, you might want to check the pieces for extra plastic that would stop it from sliding together. Even with that check you will still need to tap the bottom on.

This is a vase to enjoy for yourself or as a gift with flowers to someone special

This snowman decided to take a trip to the beach and he found a giant (to him) seashell to ride.
The seashell was 3d scanned. My wife, Annelle, made a clay snowman and he was scanned. I put them together (using Tinkercad) and added a ring for a hook.
It includes a hole in the bottom, so you can insert a light (LED please, no melting desired).
Print with no supports.

Brought to you by www.fused3D.com where you can get 3D Printer Painters Tape, and Filaments. The original: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11906 - Fan Grille
Icons from Geek Chic: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:50130 I've included some of my own icons, and a Text Feature as well.

Just mess with the settings. Make sure to make the Icon/Text and the Inner Thickness smaller or atleast the same as the Outer Frame Thickness and that's it. Some icons may need more or less Vanes to be printable and stay together.
Some icons may not work at all, or partially work. Let me know if you have problems, issues. Printable without support.
